thread.title: Israeli Police Interview Netanyahu As Part Of Reported Corruption Probe
thread.title_full: Israeli Police Interview Netanyahu As Part Of Reported Corruption Probe

author: Jack Davis
title: Israeli Police Interview Netanyahu As Part Of Reported Corruption Probe
text:
Israeli Police Interview Netanyahu As Part Of Reported Corruption Probe "There won't be anything ..." Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was questioned at his official residence Monday as police sought information in what the Israeli media have characterized as a corruption investigation of Netanyahu and his family. 
Police arrived Monday evening, local time. Local media reports suggested the questioning could take several hours. 
Israeli media have reported that Netanyahu is under suspicion of accepting large gifts of money from businessmen. Advertisement - story continues below Trump: UN Causes Problems, Not Living Up To Potential 
Britain’s The Guardian reported Monday that Netanyahu has been under investigation for eight months. PM Netanyahu's police interrogation as a suspect in crime started half an hour ago, at 6:15 pm. https://t.co/Bjy3AdfiW1 
— Noga Tarnopolsky (@NTarnopolsky) January 2, 2017 
Erel Margalit, an opposition lawmaker, has been calling for an investigation, alleging that donors improperly gave money to Netanyahu. Advertisement - story continues below 
Speaking publicly Monday, Netanyahu denied allegations of wrongdoing. Police arrive at the residence of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to question him as part of a graft probe https://t.co/7byQ4KDlIy pic.twitter.com/zbb8mjzd4k 
— AFP news agency (@AFP) January 2, 2017 
“We’ve been paying attention to reports in the media, we are hearing the celebratory mood and the atmosphere in the television studios and the corridors of the opposition, and I would like to tell them, stop with the celebrations, don’t rush,” he said. 
“There won’t be anything because there is nothing,” he said. Advertisement - story continues below Trending Stories
